parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the provided post.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>False. The post does not refer to any specific parliamentary candidate. It promotes a book discussion about freedom and the role of literature, featuring two authors. While the themes might have political undertones, no specific candidate or party is mentioned.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True.  The post is a paid advertisement on Facebook, a public platform, and aims to reach a wide audience interested in literature and political discussions. The reach estimate is ">1M", indicating a broad target.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>False. The primary objective of the post is to promote a book discussion and indirectly, the books themselves. While the themes of freedom and courage might resonate with voters, there is no explicit call to action to vote for or against any particular candidate or party. The post does not directly advocate for any political position related to the parliamentary elections.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>True. The post can be considered a form of promotion for a cultural event (book discussion). It informs the public about a discussion on relevant topics (freedom, courage, literature in the digital age).  It does not overtly attempt to sway public opinion towards a specific political outcome.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>Not applicable. The post doesn't express a personal opinion; it promotes a public event.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>502775732812107</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The Facebook post promotes a book discussion on themes of freedom and courage, featuring authors who have written about democracy. While these themes have political undertones, the post itself does not explicitly endorse or oppose any candidate or party participating in the parliamentary elections. The post's primary objective is to promote the book discussion and indirectly, the books.  The lack of any direct or indirect reference to specific candidates, coupled with the post's focus on a cultural event, suggests it does not constitute electoral propaganda under Article 98 t). The paid nature of the post on a public platform broadens its reach, but this alone does not automatically classify it as electoral propaganda.  The content is more aligned with cultural promotion and journalistic reporting of a public event.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>FALSE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates/>
<responsible-party-or-group>Editura Litera</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police/>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
